error.signature: Could not resolve all dependencies for configuration
error.regex: Could not resolve all (?:files|dependencies) for configuration|Could not find .* in any of the following sources

verdict.summary: Gradle dependency resolution failure occurs when Gradle cannot find a declared dependency in any configured repository, when version constraints conflict, or when network issues prevent downloading artifacts.

dead_ends.action: Adding mavenLocal() as the first repository to work around resolution failures
dead_ends.why_fails: mavenLocal() uses the local Maven repository (~/.m2/repository), which may contain stale, corrupted, or snapshot artifacts. Builds that depend on mavenLocal() are not reproducible across machines. It can mask real resolution problems by serving outdated artifacts.

dead_ends.action: Disabling dependency verification or checksum validation to force resolution
dead_ends.why_fails: Dependency verification exists to prevent supply chain attacks and corrupted downloads. Disabling it may allow tampered or incomplete artifacts to be used, introducing security vulnerabilities or hard-to-diagnose runtime errors.

workarounds.action: Verify the dependency coordinates (groupId, artifactId, version) are correct and the repository is configured
workarounds.how: 1. Search for the dependency on search.maven.org to verify the correct coordinates. 2. Check that the repository hosting the artifact is declared in build.gradle: repositories { mavenCentral() } or the appropriate custom repository URL. 3. For private/internal artifacts, ensure the repository URL, credentials, and authentication are configured correctly. 4. Run './gradlew dependencies --configuration runtimeClasspath' to see the full resolution result.

workarounds.action: Use Gradle's dependency resolution strategy to handle version conflicts explicitly
workarounds.how: 1. Add a resolution strategy: configurations.all { resolutionStrategy { failOnVersionConflict() } } to surface conflicts. 2. Force specific versions: resolutionStrategy { force 'group:artifact:version' }. 3. Use a platform/BOM: implementation platform('org.springframework.boot:spring-boot-dependencies:3.2.0') for consistent versions. 4. Check network connectivity and proxy settings if artifacts cannot be downloaded. 5. Run with --refresh-dependencies to bypass the cache if a corrupted artifact is suspected.

leads_to.condition: when dependency resolution partially succeeds but wrong versions cause compilation failure
when forced version resolution picks an incompatible version at runtime

preceded_by.condition: when investigating a build failure reveals that the root cause is unresolvable dependencies
when migrating from Maven to Gradle and dependency declarations are not correctly translated

frequently_confused_with.distinction: Gradle dependency resolution failure means a dependency cannot be found or downloaded at all; Maven dependency convergence error means multiple versions of the same dependency exist. Gradle can also have convergence issues, but this error is about resolution failure.
